labour can belong only to those who are capable of labour, and implicitly denies to them the right to existence, the right to be supported, merely because of destitution. Were the right to existence affirmed without condition or limit few would be likely to claim a right to labour for such means of existence as they already hed an acknowledged right to simply in virtue of needing them.

The “right to labour’' (droit uu travail) is alto- gether different from the “right of labour'' (droit dc travaillcr) which Turget, in a famous edict signed by Louis XVI. in 1776, describes as “the property of every man, and of all property the first, the most sacred, and the most imprescriptible.'' By the “right of labour'’ was meant the right of every man to feel freedom as a labourer3 the right of every man to be uninterfered with by Monarchs or Parliaments, by Corporations or Combinations, in his search for labour, in the exercise of his laculties of labour, and in the disposal or enjoyment of the products of his labour. The “right to

’ labour’' means a right on the part of the labourer

to have labour supplied to him, and necessarily implies that labour must be so organised and regu- lated that all labourers can be supplied with labour. The one right—that affirmed by physiocratists, economistS, free-tradem, and liberale of all classes—- signifies a right to such liberty as cannot be with- held without manifest injustice.
